docs.title: Welcome to the HDRUK Chest Pain Collaboration Docs
docs.text: This is a collection of the docs for the project and code snippets to help us all collaborate and share tools.

docs.title: Study Questions
docs.text:
1. Does regional variation in the use of early rule out pathways for patients with possible myocardial infarction impact on healthcare utilization and patient safety?

  2. Do hospital admission rates and safety outcomes differ by age, sex and ethnic groups?

docs.title: Objective
docs.text: Our aim is to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of the assessment of patients presenting to Emergency Departments with possible acute myocardial infarction across the United Kingdom in order to identify areas of variation in practice and opportunities for quality improvement.

docs.title: Population of Interest
docs.text: • Consecutive patients age 18 years or older at presentation who present to the Emergency Department or Acute Medicial Receiving Unit with possible myocardial infarction to any participating hospital for a 12 month period from October 2021 to October 2022 will be included within the study. Patients with possible myocardial infarction are identified if they have at least one measurement of cardiac troponin performed within 24 hours of attendance and will be eligible for inclusion. Patients will be excluded if they do not have an NHS number (England) or Community Health Index (CHI) number in Scotland to enable linkage.

docs.title: Primary Efficacy Outcome
docs.text: The proportion of patients discharged directly from the Emergency Department

docs.title: Primary Safety Endpoint
docs.text: Myocardial infarction or cardiac death within 30 days from discharge

docs.title: Secondary Endpoints
docs.text:
• Duration of index hospital stay
  • Any reattendance within 30 days of discharge
  • Myocardial infarction within 30 days of discharge
  • Cardiac death within 30 days of discharge
  • Cardiovascular death within 30 days of discharge
  • All cause death within 30 days of discharge
  • Coronary angiography during index presentation or within 30 days of discharge
  • Coronary revascularisation during index presentation or within 30 days of discharge

docs.title: Code
docs.text: This part of the documentation contains the code-snippets and functions used for data preparation and analysis. It focuses on using as structured an approach as possible using an information-oriented approach. Use it as a reference for the technical implementation of the chest_pain object code.

docs.title: Data Models
docs.text:
This area contains the key documentation pertaining to the desired data models for the project.

Below is a summary of the key items for the project

docs.title: Essential data
docs.text:
1. Demographics
  2. Age (number [%] <40 years, 40-49, 50-59, 60-69, 70-79, 80-89, >90 years)

  3. Sex (number [%] women)

  4. Laboratory data

  5. First cardiac troponin concentration (number [%] <5 ng/L, 5 ng/L to URL, above URL)
  6. Maximum cardiac troponin concentration in 24 hours (number [%] <5 ng/L, 5 ng/L to URL, above URL)

  7. Serial cardiac troponin measurments (number [%] 1, 2, 3 or more)

  8. Index diagnosis

  9. SNOMED codes for Emergency Department (provisional diagnosis)

  10. ICD-10 codes for hospital discharge (final diagnosis)

  11. Outcomes

  12. Proportion discharged directly from Emergency Department (number [%])
  13. Myocardial infarction or cardiac death 30 days from discharge (number [%])
  14. Duration of index hospital stay (number [%])(<2 hours, 2-4 hours, 5-24 hours, 25-48 hours, 49-72 hours, 73-96 hours, 97-120 hours, 121-144 hours, >145 hours)
  15. Any non-elective reattendance within 30 days of discharge (number [%])

docs.title: Desirable data
docs.text:
1. Demographics
  2. Ethnicity (number [%] of patients stratified by census ethnic grouping: White, Mixed or multiple ethnic groups, Asian or Asian British, Black or Black Caribbean or African, Other, Unknown)

  3. Social and economic deprivation (number [%] by Scottish Index of Multiple Deprivation [SIMD] score in Scotland or Townsend Deprivation score in England by quintiles)

  4. Cardiovascular risk factors from GP Read or SNOMED codes

  5. Smoking status (number [%] current, former, non, e-cigarette)
  6. Diabetes mellitus (number [%] yes or no)
  7. Hypertension (number [%] yes or no)
  8. Hyperlipidemia (number [%], prescription of a lipid lowering therapy)
  9. Past medical history from HES or SMR01 and or GP Read codes (lifetime look back)
  10. Previous myocardial infarction (number [%], yes or no)
  11. Previous coronary revascularisation (number [%], yes or no)
  12. Heart failure (number [%], yes or no)
  13. Cerebrovascular disease (number [%], yes or no)
  14. Laboratory data

  15. First estimated glomerular filtration rate (number [%] <30, 30 to 60, above 60)

  16. Outcomes

  17. Myocardial infarction within 30 days of discharge (number [%])
  18. Cardiac death within 30 days of discharge (number [%])
  19. Cardiovascular death within 30 days of discharge (number [%])
  20. All cause death within 30 days of discharge (number [%])
  21. Coronary angiography during index presentation or within 30 days of discharge (number [%])
  22. PCI or CABG during index presentation or within 30 days of discharge (number [%])

docs.title: Aspirational data
docs.text:
1. Investigations
  2. Electrocardiogram (number [%])
  3. Exercise tolerance test (number [%])
  4. CT coronary angiogram (number [%])
  5. Echocardiogram (number [%])
  6. Treatment
  7. New prescription for anti-platelet drug (number [%])

  8. New prescription for lipid lowering therapy (number [%])

  9. Follow up

  10. GP attendance within 30 days of discharge (number [%])
  11. Outpatient appointment within 30 days (number [%])

docs.title: Guides
docs.text:
Any analytics process should be reproducible. We recommend using docker containers with shell scripts to automate the entire process.

This area is currently not populated with anything specific but as the project progresses we will try to populate it with guides and lists of useful resources particularly in terms of standardising reproducible analytic pipleines.
